did.abstract: Dr. Charles Peake (1906-1993) served as the first Provost of the University of Pittsburgh from 1968 to 1971. These records contain a large amount of material, such as correspondence and reports, relating to the administration of academic and research units and developments at the university and its branch campuses.
did.langmaterial: The material in this collection is in English.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Dr. Charles Peake (1906-1993) served as the first Provost of the University of Pittsburgh from 1968 to 1971. During his time as Provost, the English Language Institute was established; the Departments of Philosophy and Physics were strengthened; and the Schenley Hotel was purchased and converted into a student union. After retirement from his position as Provost, Peake served as an adviser for the Vice Chancellor of Chinese University in Hong Kong.

Peake was from Medina, Ohio, and earned his Bachelor of Arts, Master of Arts, and doctoral degrees all from the University of Michigan. He was married to Margo Carroll and had one daughter, Terry Anne. In 1942, he enlisted in the U.S. Army and served until the end of World War II in areas throughout the United States and in New Guinea. After his military service, Peake became the Assistant Dean of the College of Literature, Science and the Arts at the University of Michigan. Peake eventually left Michigan and rose to become the Dean of the College at Knox College from 1950 to 1956. From Knox College, Peake accepted the position of Assistant Chancellor of Student Affairs at the University of Pittsburgh.

As Assistant Chancellor of Student Affairs, Peake is credited with creating new offices and programs such as the Admission Office, the Scholarship and Student Aid Office, the University Counseling Center, and the Student Employment Office, among others. In fall 1959, Peake became the Vice Chancellor of Academic Disciplines, the School of Liberal Arts and the School of General Studies. In 1967, Peake was promoted to Acting Provost in charge of all the educational and research entities except those in the Health Professions. From there, Peake was appointed the first Provost of the University on May 15, 1968.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The records of the University of Pittsburgh's first Provost, Dr. Charles Peake, contain a large amount of material relating to the administration of academic and research units and developments at the university and its branch campuses. Of note are documents relating to the division of the Modern Languages Department into the departments of Romantic Languages, Germanic Languages and Literature, Slavic Languages and Literature, and the Chinese Language and Area Center; a cooperative program with Hong Kong University; the debate over the continued presence of the Reserve Officer Training Corps on campus; and efforts to diversify the faculty and student body. The files in this collection are arranged alphabetically by the folder title designated by Provost's office staff.
